slides.title: Approval
slides.originalNotes:
Approval Gosu rules
Once a user submits (saves) a transaction, a decision process is initiated to determine if rules or authority limits require approval and if so, who should perform the first level of approval. Subsequent slides discuss each possible step and path in the decision tree.

Approval rules are run when a transaction is created and when it is edited or approved. (A transaction might require multiple approvals. Therefore, approval rules are run even when a transaction is approved.)
slides.notes:
Approval Gosu rules
Once a user submits (saves) a transaction, a decision process is initiated to determine if rules or authority limits require approval and if so, who should perform the first level of approval. Subsequent slides discuss each possible step and path in the decision tree.

Approval rules are run when a transaction is created and when it is edited or approved. (A transaction might require multiple approvals. Therefore, approval rules are run even when a transaction is approved.)

slides.title: Transaction approval
slides.originalNotes:
Transaction approval
The primary purpose of the transaction approval process is to determine if a transaction can be acted on immediately or if it must be approved by someone of sufficient authority. In the base application, no other object requires this type of approval. This functionality is implemented only for transactions because the setting of reserves and execution of payments is typically one of the most tightly controlled activities within the claims process.

Transactions are approved or rejected as a group because one transaction often influences another. For example, a single check might involve three payment transactions from two different reserve lines. If the check requires approval, for example, for a single transaction because it is for a medical
procedure and it is more than 25% over the standard amount for the specified procedure, then the check and all of its payment transactions must be set to pending. If approval was at the transaction level, then there would be ambiguity as to what to do with a check which consisted of two approved payment transaction and one pending approval payment transaction.
slides.notes:
Transaction approval
The primary purpose of the transaction approval process is to determine if a transaction can be acted on immediately or if it must be approved by someone of sufficient authority. In the base application, no other object requires this type of approval. This functionality is implemented only for transactions because the setting of reserves and execution of payments is typically one of the most tightly controlled activities within the claims process.

Transactions are approved or rejected as a group because one transaction often influences another. For example, a single check might involve three payment transactions from two different reserve lines. If the check requires approval, for example, for a single transaction because it is for a medical
procedure and it is more than 25% over the standard amount for the specified procedure, then the check and all of its payment transactions must be set to pending. If approval was at the transaction level, then there would be ambiguity as to what to do with a check which consisted of two approved payment transaction and one pending approval payment transaction.
slides.ocrText:
| Transaction approval Gi
• Transaction is usually submitted by a user who may or may not have configured
authority limits
« May also be submitted by Initial Reserve Gosu rules as part of exposure setup

• Each transaction in the set may be tested against some authority limit, a Gosu
rule, or both

• Approval always occurs at the TransactionSet level

• Either all transactions in set are approved or none are approved

slides.title: If no approval is required
slides.originalNotes:
If no approval is required
If a transaction set passes both authority limits and transaction approval rules:
A reserve set is set to Submitting" status.
A check set is set to "Awaiting Submission" status.
Recall that a check remains in "awaiting submission" status until the batch process runs, which sends the check information to the check processing system. The next status it is set to is "requested" or "requesting“ depending on the nature of the integration point to the check processing system.
slides.notes:
If no approval is required
If a transaction set passes both authority limits and transaction approval rules:
A reserve set is set to Submitting" status.
A check set is set to "Awaiting Submission" status.
Recall that a check remains in "awaiting submission" status until the batch process runs, which sends the check information to the check processing system. The next status it is set to is "requested" or "requesting“ depending on the nature of the integration point to the check processing system.
slides.ocrText:
| If no approval is required

• For reserve transactions, reserve lines are created or modified

• For payment transactions, checks are put into "awaiting submission" status

slides.title: If approval is required
slides.originalNotes:
If approval is required
If either authority limits or approval rules determine that further approval is required, the transaction set's status is set to "Pending Approval," and an activity is created and routed to the next person who must approve the transaction set.

The first time the TransactionSet is submitted, it carries with it the submitting user.

Once routed for approval, the approving user is associated with the TransactionSet and her limits are used to determine if it requires approval agaim In the base configuration, this is the next level of management, so that (for example) a manager does not see transaction sets unless they are first approved by the claims supervisor.
slides.notes:
If approval is required
If either authority limits or approval rules determine that further approval is required, the transaction set's status is set to "Pending Approval," and an activity is created and routed to the next person who must approve the transaction set.

The first time the TransactionSet is submitted, it carries with it the submitting user.

Once routed for approval, the approving user is associated with the TransactionSet and her limits are used to determine if it requires approval agaim In the base configuration, this is the next level of management, so that (for example) a manager does not see transaction sets unless they are first approved by the claims supervisor.

| If approval is required G

• The TransactionSet and all its transactions are set to "pending approval“ status

« An approval activity is created and routed according to approval routing rules

slides.title: If a transaction set is rejected if
slides.originalNotes:
If a transaction set is rejected
If a transaction set is rejected, its status is changed to Rejected. The transaction set remains in the system for record keeping purposes, but no further action is possible on the transaction set.
This means that a higher-ranked individual cannot reverse the rejection and approve the transaction set. It would be necessary to create a new transaction set with identical transactions, and then approve that.
slides.notes:
If a transaction set is rejected
If a transaction set is rejected, its status is changed to Rejected. The transaction set remains in the system for record keeping purposes, but no further action is possible on the transaction set.
This means that a higher-ranked individual cannot reverse the rejection and approve the transaction set. It would be necessary to create a new transaction set with identical transactions, and then approve that.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
At what transactional hierarchy level does approval happen?
•
•
SS oe ooo ee oe ooo ooOD

questionData.question: At what transactional hierarchy level does approval happen?
questionData.answer: At the level of the TransactionSet

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
At what transactional hierarchy level does approval happen?
•
•
The correct answer is at the level of the TransactionSet
SS See eo ee oo ooo SoD

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What happens after a transaction set is approved? Why?
•
•
SS oe ooo ee oe ooo ooOD

questionData.question: What happens after a transaction set is approved? Why?
questionData.answer: Approval rules are re-executed using the permissions of the last approving user. This enables multi-stage approvals.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What happens after a transaction set is approved? Why?
•
The correct answer is approval rules are re-executed using the permissions of the last
approving user. This enables multi-stage approvals.
SS See eo ee oo ooo SoD

slides.ocrText:
| Authority limit profiles G

An authority limit profile is a collection of authority limits assigned to one or more
users.

* Can be pre-defined (created once and shared across multiple users)

* Can be custom (created for a single user)

slides.title: Evaluation of authority limits by
slides.ocrText:
| Evaluation of authority limits by Gosu rules Gi
• Itis possible to use Gosu rules, rather than the built-in checker, to evaluate
authority limits
• To do this:

1. Disable authority limit checking for transactions by setting CheckAuthorityLimits to false in
config.xml

<param name="CheckAuthorityLimits" value='

2. Write selective rules that check users’ authority limits and reject or require approval
accordingly

3. Write validation rules that check against limits for all other transactions

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
lfauser has a $15000 approval limit for Comprehensive coverage, what
oo effect does that have on their approval limit for Collision coverage?
SS oe ooo ee oe ooo ooOD
Gi

questionData.question: Lfauser has a $15000 approval limit for Comprehensive coverage, what
questionData.answer: Oo effect does that have on their approval limit for Collision coverage? The correct answer is unless they have another limit line that enables Collision coverage, they cannot approve Collision transactions at all.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer a
lfauser has a $15000 approval limit for Comprehensive coverage, what
oo effect does that have on their approval limit for Collision coverage?
The correct answer is unless they have another limit line that enables Collision
coverage, they cannot approve Collision transactions at all.
SS See eo ee oo ooo SoD

slides.title: Transaction approval and approval routing
slides.ocrText:
| Transaction approval and approval routing Gi

• Transaction approval rules implement logic for approval requirements that cannot
be captured in an authority limit, such as

* Logic beyond the given limit types
• Logic tied to attributes other than coverage and cost type
* Logic that cannot easily be associated to given users

• Approval routing rules assign approval ownership

slides.title: Transaction approval rules
slides.ocrText:
| Transaction approval rules Gi

• Typically, all (relevant) rules are executed
* The cause for additional approvals will be added to the approval activity
• Atransaction set either requires or does not require approval
* There may be additional causes that the approving supervisor should know about

• By executing all rules, the approval activity will contain a list of all limits that have been
exceeded

#) TransactionApprovalRules.grs |

v ims Transaction Approval Rules
#) Y TAPo1000 - PIP

iv} TAP04000 - Claim And Exposures Should Be At Ability To Pay
=} |\¥} TAPOS000 - Optionally Check For Duplicate Checks

slides.title: The requireApproval() method
slides.ocrText:
| The requireApproval() method Gi

• Syntax: transactionSet.requireApproval("reason").
« Method only on available the TransactionSet object (not Transaction or Check)

USES:
uses gw.api.locale.DisplayKey
CONDITION (transactionSet : entity.TransactionSet):

return transactionSet.Subtype == TC_CHECKSET
ACTION (transactionSet ‘ransactionSet, actions : gw.rules.Action):

var totalIncurredAmt = util. financials.CustomCales.MyTotalIncurredNet.getAmount (transactionSet.Claim)
var exceedAmount = new gw.api.financials.CurrencyAmount (20000, totalIncurredAmt.Currency)

transactionSet. requireApproval (
DisplayXey.get("Total Incurred on the claim exceeds {0}",

gw.api.util.CurrencyUtil. renderAsCurrency(exceedAmount) ) )

slides.title: Approval routing rules
slides.ocrText:
| Approval routing rules Gi

• Approval routing is similar to assignment, but for approval activities

* Become active when an approval activity is created

• One set of rules for transaction set approval routing, and one for bulk invoice
approval routing

* Typically, not all relevant rules are executed

« As soon as one rule makes assignment, execution exits out of rule set

Y DF Rule Sets

slides.title: Approval routing methods:
slides.ocrText:
| Approval routing methods:
approveByUserSupervisor
Syntax: transactionSet.approveByUserSupervisor().
« No parameters
+ Assigns to group supervisor based on the user who submitted the transaction

+ If submitting user is in multiple groups, goes to the supervisor of the owning group

CONDITION (transactionSet entity .TransactionSet) :

return /* This action vill

transactionSet.approveByUserSup
ACTION (transactionSet : entity.TransactionSet, actions : gw.rules.Action):
actions.exit()

END

slides.title: Approval routing methods:
slides.ocrText:
| Approval routing methods: Gi
approveByGroupSupervisor
Syntax: transactionSet.approveByGroupSupervisor().
« No parameters; routed to supervisor of owning group

• Returns false if user needing approval is group supervisor

entity .TransactionSet) :

slides.title: Approval routing methods: setApprovingUser
slides.ocrText:
| Approval routing methods: setApprovingUser Gi

Syntax: transactionSet.setApprovingUser(user, group).
* Routed to specified user and specified group

« Use Queries and/or findUserByUserName() to retrieve users and groups

ACTION (transactionSet : entity.TransactionSet, actions : gw.rules.Action):

r croup sl or.

transactionSet.setApprovingUser (util.RuleGroups. instance.getHeadquartersSupervisor(),
util.RuleGroups. instance.getHeadquarters ())

slides.title: Exiting from approval routing rules
slides.ocrText:
| Exiting from approval routing rules Gi

• After object is successfully assigned, you typically want no other rules to be
executed

• Approval routing methods are Boolean — return true if the assignment was successful
* Otherwise, fall through to a default assignment rule
• Use actions.exit() as with assignment rules

CONDITION (transactionSet : entity.TransactionSet):

return /* I ¥

the request is not the
transactionSet.approveByGroupSupervisor ()
ACTION (transactionSet : entity.TransactionSet, actions : gw.rules.Action):

actions.exit()

END

slides.title: Appendix: Straight-Through Invoice
slides.ocrText:
Appendix: Straight-Through Invoice Gi
Processing (STIP)
« Automates the approval and payment of many routine invoices

« Payments can be made against Reserve Lines, at either the Claim or the
Exposure level

• For information about configuring STIP, see the on “Configuring Vendor Services”

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What do transaction approval rules and approval routing rules,
oo respectively, do?
SS oe ooo ee oe ooo ooOD

questionData.question: What do transaction approval rules and approval routing rules,
questionData.answer: Oo respectively, do? The correct answer is: Transaction approval rules implement approval requirement logic that cannot be captured in an authority limit. Approval routing rules assign approval ownership.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What do transaction approval rules and approval routing rules,
oo respectively, do?
•
The correct answer is:
Transaction approval rules implement approval requirement logic that cannot be
captured in an authority limit.
Approval routing rules assign approval ownership.
SS See eo ee oo ooo SoD
